description: Over 80% of computers run Microsoft Operating systems. As a result, the Microsoft Certified Solutions Associate is one of the first steps for those seeking to start a technical career. The MCSA: Windows Server covers topics that are “must know” for anyone responsible for deploying, maintaining and supporting Windows servers in a corporate or enterprise environment. Server systems often form a critical piece of the day-to-day operations for any business. The MCSA covers topics that will help the learner ensure their computing environment is functional and stable.
name: MCSA Windows Server 2016 - 70-740
subtitle: Installation, Storage, and Compute with Windows Server 2016

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike take you through installing, upgrading, and migrating to Windows Server 2016. They begin by looking at installation hardware requirements and then go over the different version's specifics. Next, they begin their demonstration of a standard installation.
episodes.title: Install, Upgrade and Migrate
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.006 --> 00:00:10.006
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.068 --> 00:00:16.153
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.153 --> 00:00:18.221
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and

4
00:00:18.221 --> 00:00:22.910
in today's episode we begin
our series on installation.

5
00:00:22.910 --> 00:00:25.290
This is a long title, so bear with me.

6
00:00:25.290 --> 00:00:29.770
Installation, storage and compute with
Windows Server 2016, that's right,

7
00:00:29.770 --> 00:00:32.900
the new hotness available from Microsoft.

8
00:00:32.900 --> 00:00:36.710
Joining us in the studio today to
lend his expertise on that topic,

9
00:00:36.710 --> 00:00:39.140
the Microsoft man himself,
Mr. Mike Rodrick.

10
00:00:39.140 --> 00:00:39.970
Mike, welcome back, sir.

11
00:00:39.970 --> 00:00:40.800
How's it going today?

12
00:00:40.800 --> 00:00:41.888
>> It's going fantastic.

13
00:00:41.888 --> 00:00:45.460
I'm excited cuz we are starting
that journey, as you said,

14
00:00:45.460 --> 00:00:48.540
with Server 2016 and
I love My Windows Server.

15
00:00:48.540 --> 00:00:50.470
>> You do.
>> And man, what a title.

16
00:00:50.470 --> 00:00:51.610
>> I know.
>> I'm glad it was on you, not me.

17
00:00:51.610 --> 00:00:53.000
I didn't want to have to say that.

18
00:00:53.000 --> 00:00:55.362
>> Little verbose [LAUGH].

19
00:00:55.362 --> 00:00:57.754
>> Barely fits across the bottom
of our screen down there.

20
00:00:57.754 --> 00:01:02.361
But as you can see, we are gonna be
installing, looking at storage and

21
00:01:02.361 --> 00:01:04.180
looking at compute.

22
00:01:04.180 --> 00:01:09.150
When it comes to Windows Server 2016,
gearing up for those new

23
00:01:09.150 --> 00:01:14.740
set of exams that are gonna be coming
out pretty soon for 2016 with your MCSA.

24
00:01:14.740 --> 00:01:17.191
And they've rearranged
things a little bit, so

25
00:01:17.191 --> 00:01:21.636
don't expect it to go like it did
with 2012 and 2008 and 2003 and 2000.

26
00:01:21.636 --> 00:01:23.472
Of course,
they just had to change it up, you know?

27
00:01:23.472 --> 00:01:24.134
>> Of course.

28
00:01:24.134 --> 00:01:26.748
>> We kind of used to start off with
things like Active Directory and DNS.

29
00:01:26.748 --> 00:01:31.343
Here we're gonna start out with again,
learning about installing it,

30
00:01:31.343 --> 00:01:34.690
setting up storage, working with compute.

31
00:01:34.690 --> 00:01:37.900
And then we move into gosh,

32
00:01:37.900 --> 00:01:40.460
I think the second one deals
with some of the infrastructure.

33
00:01:40.460 --> 00:01:43.150
And then the third one is gonna deal
with identity where we get into

34
00:01:43.150 --> 00:01:46.310
Active Directory, rights management,
federation and all that good stuff.

35
00:01:46.310 --> 00:01:49.380
So this one again,
is a first in the series.

36
00:01:49.380 --> 00:01:53.630
And with all of Microsoft Server's
classes where we first start out,

37
00:01:53.630 --> 00:01:56.170
what's the first thing
we have learned about?

38
00:01:56.170 --> 00:01:57.360
Getting it installed, right?

39
00:01:57.360 --> 00:02:00.360
We can't do much when it's
on that disk in our hands.

40
00:02:00.360 --> 00:02:02.850
So we've gotta put it in there and
get this installed.

41
00:02:02.850 --> 00:02:04.270
So that's what we're gonna do.

42
00:02:04.270 --> 00:02:09.030
And before we go to install, we need to
know about all the minimum requirements.

43
00:02:09.030 --> 00:02:12.808
So that we can be successful with our
installs, so let's cover those real quick.

44
00:02:12.808 --> 00:02:16.810
We're not gonna drag it out, just
a little bit of memorization to it and

45
00:02:17.860 --> 00:02:20.930
they might ask you one or
two questions on the exam about it.

46
00:02:20.930 --> 00:02:26.580
So like I said I wouldn't spend too much
time remember, they've actually simplified

47
00:02:26.580 --> 00:02:31.340
it a little bit addition wise at least for
now it's a lot better than it was.

48
00:02:31.340 --> 00:02:37.390
So processor wise,
1.4 gigahertz 64-bit processor.

49
00:02:37.390 --> 00:02:41.610
Again, when we talk about these we're
talking minimum requirements, right?

50
00:02:41.610 --> 00:02:43.700
That means you can
successfully install it,

51
00:02:43.700 --> 00:02:45.690
you might not like what
you've got afterwards and

52
00:02:45.690 --> 00:02:49.310
you might not be able to run anything
on it, but you can get it installed.

53
00:02:49.310 --> 00:02:51.540
So one point-
>> I can see them getting a real bad rap.

54
00:02:51.540 --> 00:02:55.220
People going, man this thing
runs horrible, it's so slow.

55
00:02:55.220 --> 00:02:58.550
You're running it on the bare
requirements there, buddy.

56
00:02:58.550 --> 00:03:00.616
It will run, but
we didn't say it would run well [LAUGH].

57
00:03:00.616 --> 00:03:01.255
>> That's right.

58
00:03:01.255 --> 00:03:04.178
That's why they're called
minimum requirements.

59
00:03:04.178 --> 00:03:08.650
1.4 gigahertz, 64-bit processor,
compatible with a 64-bit instruction set.

60
00:03:08.650 --> 00:03:13.483
You do need to support a second
level address translation or

61
00:03:13.483 --> 00:03:16.780
SLAT for short, as well as NX and or DEP.

62
00:03:16.780 --> 00:03:20.459
The no execution bit or
the data execution prevention,

63
00:03:20.459 --> 00:03:25.200
depending on what platform
you're on there, Intel, AMD.

64
00:03:25.200 --> 00:03:29.410
So those are our requirements for
our processor, for

65
00:03:29.410 --> 00:03:32.870
our memory, 512 megabytes of RAM,
yeah, not very much.

66
00:03:32.870 --> 00:03:36.170
But again, that's just to get
the operating system installed.

67
00:03:36.170 --> 00:03:39.330
If you're running Core, you might be
able to get away with using that if you

68
00:03:39.330 --> 00:03:41.170
don't dump too many rolls on there.

69
00:03:41.170 --> 00:03:43.600
But as you add more and
more rolls, remember,

70
00:03:43.600 --> 00:03:47.240
these are just the minimum requirements
for the operating system itself.

71
00:03:47.240 --> 00:03:50.550
Nothing to do with what you're gonna
run on top of that operating system.

72
00:03:50.550 --> 00:03:54.800
If you're gonna make it a domain
controller, a DNS server, A DHCP server.

73
00:03:54.800 --> 00:03:56.783
Each one of those roles has requirements.

74
00:03:56.783 --> 00:04:00.940
So you'd have to start adding up, all
right, I need 512 for my operating system.

75
00:04:00.940 --> 00:04:03.657
I need a gig for [INAUDIBLE] and all this
kind of thing, iou'd add them all up.

76
00:04:03.657 --> 00:04:04.980
So keep that in mind.

77
00:04:04.980 --> 00:04:11.610
But 512 minimum with error correction code
or ECC type memory is the way we wanna go.

78
00:04:11.610 --> 00:04:14.780
I know I've read a couple of notes too.

79
00:04:14.780 --> 00:04:18.288
If you try to do it in a virtual
machine with 512 megs of RAM,

80
00:04:18.288 --> 00:04:22.610
it's probably gonna fail,
even though 512 is listed as the minimum.

81
00:04:22.610 --> 00:04:26.620
They say bump it up to about 800,
900 megs, get it installed,

82
00:04:26.620 --> 00:04:30.900
then you can drop it back down to 512
if you really are that tight on memory.

83
00:04:30.900 --> 00:04:34.720
It has to do with the expansion of all
the files and get everything set up.

84
00:04:34.720 --> 00:04:35.490
It can run with 512,

85
00:04:35.490 --> 00:04:40.310
it fails if you try to do
the installation with that 512 in a VM.

86
00:04:40.310 --> 00:04:44.301
So something to keep in mind again,
that's not in the exam,

87
00:04:44.301 --> 00:04:48.702
that's just for your FYI,
if that's not redundant for your FYI.

88
00:04:48.702 --> 00:04:50.084
>> For your information.

89
00:04:50.084 --> 00:04:52.831
>> So the PIN number for
the ATM machine is.

90
00:04:52.831 --> 00:04:53.562
>> And your NIC card.

91
00:04:53.562 --> 00:04:56.616
>> And my NIC card [LAUGH].

92
00:04:56.616 --> 00:05:00.648
So 32 or 512 megs of RAM,
32 gigs of hard drive space, again,

93
00:05:00.648 --> 00:05:03.160
get it installed, get everything there.

94
00:05:03.160 --> 00:05:07.080
It does not allow ATA, PATA, IDE or

95
00:05:07.080 --> 00:05:12.698
enhanced IDE, EIDE, for
any of my drives really,

96
00:05:12.698 --> 00:05:17.026
for boot, for page or for data drives.

97
00:05:17.026 --> 00:05:17.664
>> Doesn't like them.

98
00:05:17.664 --> 00:05:18.900
>> Doesn't like them.

99
00:05:18.900 --> 00:05:23.430
So that technology is finally
kinda hit the end there.

100
00:05:23.430 --> 00:05:24.780
Can't use that at all.

101
00:05:24.780 --> 00:05:29.540
Network adapter is gonna be needed, at
least a gigabit throughput would be nice.

102
00:05:29.540 --> 00:05:31.190
They say that's a minimum requirement.

103
00:05:32.320 --> 00:05:35.110
I'm pretty sure even if I had a ten
megabit adapter it would probably

104
00:05:35.110 --> 00:05:36.160
let me install.

105
00:05:36.160 --> 00:05:38.770
Don't quote me on that,
I've never tested it or tried it.

106
00:05:38.770 --> 00:05:41.729
But I don't know that it would actually
look at the throughput on your adapter,

107
00:05:41.729 --> 00:05:42.310
interesting.

108
00:05:42.310 --> 00:05:43.058
>> Yeah, how would it know that?

109
00:05:43.058 --> 00:05:45.743
>> They do call it out, so
for the exam, remember,

110
00:05:45.743 --> 00:05:49.557
Mike told you at least a gigabit
throughput on your network adapter.

111
00:05:49.557 --> 00:05:53.382
>> Maybe they're saying you need to use
a gigabit because you're gonna be running

112
00:05:53.382 --> 00:05:56.270
all these services that
needs some decent bandwidth.

113
00:05:56.270 --> 00:05:58.666
>> Yeah, and you will be really hard
pressed to find anything less than

114
00:05:58.666 --> 00:05:59.473
a gigabyte nowadays.

115
00:05:59.473 --> 00:06:00.912
>> Who the heck's running ten megabit?

116
00:06:00.912 --> 00:06:01.892
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah,

117
00:06:01.892 --> 00:06:04.664
you can go down to a hardware store or
a swap store and

118
00:06:04.664 --> 00:06:08.030
maybe find a 10/100 card but
it's gonna be difficult.

119
00:06:08.030 --> 00:06:10.470
And then you gotta find a driver for
it so.

120
00:06:10.470 --> 00:06:11.370
What else?

121
00:06:11.370 --> 00:06:13.710
Need to support
the pre-execution environment or

122
00:06:13.710 --> 00:06:18.530
pixie boot if we're gonna do any
network installation of images.

123
00:06:18.530 --> 00:06:22.547
So requirement-wise, really not that
steep, those are minimum requirements.

124
00:06:22.547 --> 00:06:28.660
1.4 gigahertz, 512 megs of RAM,
32 gigs of hard drive space and

125
00:06:28.660 --> 00:06:31.710
a gigabit network adapter
will get you started.

126
00:06:32.740 --> 00:06:36.690
Then we've gotta talk about
the good old additions.

127
00:06:36.690 --> 00:06:39.650
And there's a few different additions
as I was saying earlier, but

128
00:06:39.650 --> 00:06:42.270
it doesn't seem to be quite
as many as there used to be.

129
00:06:42.270 --> 00:06:47.530
And really three mains ones that we'll
end up dealing with throughout the MCSA

130
00:06:47.530 --> 00:06:49.850
track that we have to worry about.

131
00:06:49.850 --> 00:06:52.040
But good to know the others just in case.

132
00:06:52.040 --> 00:06:53.590
You've got the data center version,

133
00:06:53.590 --> 00:06:56.540
that's the top dog,
the big bad boy of the server world.

134
00:06:56.540 --> 00:07:01.702
The data center edition is really designed
for highly virtualized environments and

135
00:07:01.702 --> 00:07:04.912
data centers,
hence the name data center version.

136
00:07:04.912 --> 00:07:05.597
>> Who would have thought?

137
00:07:05.597 --> 00:07:07.950
>> I know, right?

138
00:07:07.950 --> 00:07:10.050
Remember the license a little
bit different with data center.

139
00:07:10.050 --> 00:07:15.340
With data center, you're paying thousands
of dollars, upwards towards the gosh,

140
00:07:15.340 --> 00:07:18.260
I wanna say 6, $8,000 for
a data center license.

141
00:07:18.260 --> 00:07:21.880
But you get unlimited virtual
licenses when you get that.

142
00:07:21.880 --> 00:07:23.720
So you get that one physical install and

143
00:07:23.720 --> 00:07:27.840
then unlimited virtual licenses so,
that's why you spend the extra money.

144
00:07:27.840 --> 00:07:31.035
And in a highly virtualized environment,
that would make sense.

145
00:07:31.035 --> 00:07:36.155
I mean if I'm gonna have 100 virtual
servers, I can buy one license for

146
00:07:36.155 --> 00:07:37.992
8,000 bucks to cover all of those.

147
00:07:37.992 --> 00:07:39.940
You've gotta work out
the math in your environment,

148
00:07:39.940 --> 00:07:41.810
but sounds like a good deal to me.

149
00:07:41.810 --> 00:07:43.290
What else?

150
00:07:43.290 --> 00:07:47.860
Standard is the next one
down from data center.

151
00:07:47.860 --> 00:07:51.866
That one is good for physical
environments, small shops where you

152
00:07:51.866 --> 00:07:56.241
actually have physical servers you
install on or a few virtualization.

153
00:07:56.241 --> 00:07:59.189
Right, where it's not a heavily
virtualized environment, but

154
00:07:59.189 --> 00:08:02.150
we are going to be running
some virtual machines.

155
00:08:02.150 --> 00:08:05.070
Because, with standard,
you get one physical install, and

156
00:08:05.070 --> 00:08:07.370
you get two virtual licenses.

157
00:08:07.370 --> 00:08:11.765
Run you about 800 bucks, 600,
800 bucks, I think for a standard.

158
00:08:11.765 --> 00:08:15.385
Again, all of these prices, this is as of
maybe this morning when we're recording

159
00:08:15.385 --> 00:08:18.645
this, that could very well be
different by the time you watch this.

160
00:08:18.645 --> 00:08:20.745
So, make sure you go check that out and
do your research.

161
00:08:20.745 --> 00:08:24.325
That's not a, prices are not
an exam type question anyway,

162
00:08:24.325 --> 00:08:25.605
just kind of for your information.

163
00:08:26.735 --> 00:08:30.205
So, standard primarily for
your physical, minimally virtualized.

164
00:08:30.205 --> 00:08:34.560
You also have an Essentials edition, which
is kinda like the old small business,

165
00:08:34.560 --> 00:08:39.210
where up to 25 users is all you can have,

166
00:08:39.210 --> 00:08:42.950
I think it's 50 devices
can connect into it.

167
00:08:42.950 --> 00:08:46.680
That's one that you're not gonna find,
you'd have to actually, I don't even know

168
00:08:46.680 --> 00:08:50.150
where you get that one, I think you
have to go to Microsoft to get that.

169
00:08:50.150 --> 00:08:52.310
There's also MultiPoint Premium Server for

170
00:08:52.310 --> 00:08:55.820
volume license customers
in academic segments.

171
00:08:55.820 --> 00:08:57.260
So, if you're in the academic,

172
00:08:57.260 --> 00:09:00.560
you can get a discount on the price for
MultiPoint Premium Server.

173
00:09:00.560 --> 00:09:04.250
There's Storage Server, which has
both a standard and a work group.

174
00:09:04.250 --> 00:09:09.410
Those are from the OEM channel only so you
would buy an appliance that was running

175
00:09:09.410 --> 00:09:14.360
Microsoft Storage Server 2016 and
then there's also a Hyper V-server,

176
00:09:14.360 --> 00:09:16.450
which is actually a free
download from Microsoft.

177
00:09:16.450 --> 00:09:17.690
>> Hold on now.

178
00:09:17.690 --> 00:09:20.070
I know Microsoft,
they don't give anything away for free.

179
00:09:20.070 --> 00:09:23.650
Is this like their gateway drug to
get you hooked on their products and

180
00:09:23.650 --> 00:09:24.570
you come back for more?

181
00:09:24.570 --> 00:09:25.990
[LAUGH]
>> They'll get you started.

182
00:09:25.990 --> 00:09:29.540
Right, but now you need something to
manage all those Hyper V servers with.

183
00:09:29.540 --> 00:09:30.537
>> So,
you're gonna need a system center, and

184
00:09:30.537 --> 00:09:32.008
you're gonna have some
of that to [CROSSTALK].

185
00:09:32.008 --> 00:09:32.674
>> Yeah.

186
00:09:32.674 --> 00:09:34.190
[LAUGH] Yeah, buy that system center.

187
00:09:34.190 --> 00:09:36.510
>> Sure.
Get your server for free, but

188
00:09:36.510 --> 00:09:38.700
pay $30,000 for a system center.

189
00:09:38.700 --> 00:09:39.460
>> Exactly.

190
00:09:39.460 --> 00:09:42.990
>> But yeah, there's a hyper version,
free download.

191
00:09:42.990 --> 00:09:44.950
And it's just that,
it's just the hypervisor.

192
00:09:44.950 --> 00:09:48.530
So if you wanna set up a,
you got a core platform hardware,

193
00:09:48.530 --> 00:09:52.450
you wanna run Hyper-V on there, you can
download this version and install it.

194
00:09:52.450 --> 00:09:53.820
Again, no bells and whistles,

195
00:09:53.820 --> 00:09:57.140
none of the rest of the operating system,
just your hypervisor, but

196
00:09:57.140 --> 00:10:01.790
maybe that's all you need, and you can
manage it with your normal Hyper-V tools.

197
00:10:01.790 --> 00:10:05.450
All right, so, for us really like I said

198
00:10:05.450 --> 00:10:09.990
Three big ones that we'll deal with are
gonna be data center standard and hyper v.

199
00:10:09.990 --> 00:10:12.460
Those would be the ones that
they might test you on, but

200
00:10:12.460 --> 00:10:14.160
know the other ones just in case.

201
00:10:14.160 --> 00:10:18.510
We'll be dealing with standard
as far as demos go and

202
00:10:18.510 --> 00:10:21.200
labs go we'll be dealing with standard.

203
00:10:21.200 --> 00:10:22.795
There isn't a difference
between standard and

204
00:10:22.795 --> 00:10:25.530
datacenter any more,
I think that started back in 2008.

205
00:10:25.530 --> 00:10:29.120
In 2003 you had standard and

206
00:10:29.120 --> 00:10:32.900
enterprise, Enterprise could do
things that standard could not.

207
00:10:32.900 --> 00:10:37.470
Like with Enterprise, you could install
Enterprise level certificate authority.

208
00:10:37.470 --> 00:10:38.980
On standard, you couldn't.

209
00:10:38.980 --> 00:10:42.400
Well, that's no longer the case.

210
00:10:42.400 --> 00:10:46.640
With 2016, all the If features and
roles are available on both Standard and

211
00:10:46.640 --> 00:10:49.430
Data Center, it's a Licensing
where the differences occurs.

212
00:10:49.430 --> 00:10:54.380
You don't pay, used to be you have to bump
up to that Enterprise License just to get

213
00:10:54.380 --> 00:10:58.030
the ability to do things
like Certificate Authority.

214
00:10:58.030 --> 00:11:01.140
That's no longer the case,
you get a full set with Standard.

215
00:11:01.140 --> 00:11:04.189
Data Center just gives you
extra licensing capabilities.

216
00:11:05.960 --> 00:11:10.910
So the standard data center and
hyper V are the big ones to know about.

217
00:11:10.910 --> 00:11:17.480
When it comes to installing our server,
that is what we are going to do next.

218
00:11:17.480 --> 00:11:19.260
Well take a look at the installation and

219
00:11:19.260 --> 00:11:23.140
not a lot has changed on
the installation for server.

220
00:11:23.140 --> 00:11:25.680
So if you're familiar with doing
this in previous versions,

221
00:11:25.680 --> 00:11:28.900
you're well ahead of the game when
it comes to studying for this.

222
00:11:28.900 --> 00:11:31.150
We're gonna go through the process.

223
00:11:31.150 --> 00:11:34.220

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike take you through installing, upgrading, and migrating to Windows Server 2016. Here they finish their standard installation as well as installing Server Core 2016. Finally, they take you through common post-installation procedures like setting a static IP, setting the admin password, and joining to a domain.
episodes.title: Install, Upgrade and Migrate Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike continue taking you through installing, upgrading, and migrating to Windows Server 2016. Here they introduce you to the Desired State Configuration(DSC) which enables deploying and managing configuration data for software services and managing the environment in which these services run.
episodes.title: Install, Upgrade and Migrate Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike continue taking you through installing, upgrading, and migrating to Windows Server 2016. They show you the final piece of the Desired State Configuration(DSC) puzzle; demonstrating how to implement a Pull Server for DSC, which will automate the DSC process.
episodes.title: Install, Upgrade and Migrate Part 4

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike finish taking you through installing, upgrading, and migrating to Windows Server 2016. They show you the final piece of the Desired State Configuration(DSC) puzzle; demonstrating how to implement the DSC Pull Clients to get their configs from the Pull Server.
episodes.title: Install, Upgrade and Migrate Part 5

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike dive into the world of a new installation type called Nano inside Windows Server 2016. They talk about the basics of Nano Server as well as the scenarios that the viewer might find themselves using Nano Server. They finish with Powershell cmdlets to get the Nano installation started.
episodes.title: Install and Configure Nano Server

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Mike continue their discussion on Nano Server a new installation type in Windows Server 2016. They demonstrate how to configure a Hyper-V virtual machine ready to apply the Nano Server they created to the VM. They look at the interface and explain connecting to the server instance  as well as the some of the basic configurations such as using the Package Manager to install additional packages and driver installation.
episodes.title: Install and Configure Nano Server Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike continue their discussion on Nano Server a new installation type in Windows Server 2016. They will explore how to setup a Nano Server installation up for remote management by configuring the Trusted Hosts through WSMan.
episodes.title: Install and Configure Nano Server Part 3

topics.title: Install Windows Servers in host and compute environments

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike explore the concepts of disks and volumes inside of Windows Server 2016. They explain concepts like MBR, GPT, basic and dynamic disks as well as their respective benefits and drawbacks.
episodes.title: Configure Disks and Volumes

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike continue their exploration of disks and volumes inside of Windows Server 2016. They take a look at virtual hard disks and the formats associated with virtual disks such as VHD and VHDX. They demonstrate creating virtual disks inside of Disk Management and Powershell.
episodes.title: Configure Disks and Volumes Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explain and demonstrate implementing server storage in Windows Server 2016. They begin by looking at Storage Pools and Storage Spaces, then they implement Simple, Mirror, and Parity for disks or enclosures. Next they show you how to expand Storage Pools and finally configuring tiered storage.
episodes.title: Implement Server Storage

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explore the Data Deduplication technology in Windows Server 2016. They begin by explaining how implementing Dedup can save storage space and then walk you through installing and configuring Dedup on a 2016 server.
episodes.title: Implement Data Deduplication

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike take you through installing and configuring Hyper-V in Windows Server 2016. They begin by determining the hardware compatibility requirements for installing Hyper-V. Next, they show you how to install Hyper-V along with the Management Tools.
episodes.title: Install and Configure Hyper-V

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike continue their demo of Microsoft's Hyper-V virtualization software, showing you how to install and configure nested virtual machines. They also show you how to configure the nested VM's networking components NestedNAT and MAC Spoofing.
episodes.title: Install and Configure Hyper-V Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike walk you through configuring a Hyper-V virtual machine. They demonstrate configuring dynamic RAM options like Startup RAM, Min/Max Ram, Memory Buffer and Weight. They also show you how to configure Non-Uniform Memory Access(NUMA) and resource metering of the CPU, Memory, Network, and Disk.
episodes.title: Configure Virtual Machine Settings

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike continue working their way through Virtual Machine configurations. Here they pick up by examining Integration Services and then looking at the difference between using Gen1 and Gen2 VMs. Also covered is Enhanced Session Mode, Linux/FreeBSD VMs and their associated Integration Services, exporting/importing VMs, and finally implementation of Discrete Device Assignment(DDA).
episodes.title: Configure Virtual Machine Settings Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike take you through configuring Hyper-V Storage. They begin by creating VHDs, and VHDX files using Hyper-V Manager. Then they explain and demonstrate a crucial and convenient component called Differencing Disks which allow for rapid deployment of VMs.
episodes.title: Configure Hyper-V Storage

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike finish up their exposition on Hyper-V Storage by showing and explaining how to modify and resize VHDs. Lastly they explore the wonderful world of Hyper-V Checkpoints for quick backup/restore of VMs.
episodes.title: Configure Hyper-V Storage Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explain how to connect your Hyper-V Virtual Machines by configuring Hyper-V networking. They begin by looking at connecting a virtual Network Interface Card(NIC). From there they jump into Virtual Switch config as well as MAC address, network isolation, synthetic and legacy virtual adapters, and NIC Teaming configuration.
episodes.title: Configure Hyper-V Networking

episodes.description: In this episode, Don introduces the viewers to Hyper-V containers. He explains how they differ from traditional Docker containers and then demonstrates how to launch and manage Hyper-V containers.
episodes.title: Hyper V Containers

episodes.description: In this episode, Don introduces the viewers to Docker containers. He then shows how to install Docker support on Windows Server 2016. Finally, he demonstrates how to create and manage containers inside of Docker.
episodes.title: Docker Containers

episodes.description: In this episode, Don introduces the viewers to Docker containers. He then shows how to install Docker support on Windows Server 2016. Finally, he demonstrates how to create and manage containers inside of Docker.
episodes.title: Docker Containers Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains how to use the Network Load Balancing (NLB) feature in Windows Server 2016 to create a scale-out cluster. He then walks the viewers through installing, configuring and managing NLB in a small load-balanced cluster.
episodes.title: Network Load Balancing

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains how to use the Network Load Balancing (NLB) feature in Windows Server 2016 to create a scale-out cluster. He then walks the viewers through installing, configuring and managing NLB in a small load-balanced cluster.
episodes.title: Network Load Balancing Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains how the Failover Cluster feature works in Windows Server 2016. He explains scenarios where clusters can be used and walks the viewers through the various requirements to be met before we can install a failover cluster.
episodes.title: Failover Clustering

episodes.description: In this episode, Don continues explaining how the Failover Cluster feature works in Windows Server 2016. He demonstrates installing the Failover Cluster feature, configuring shared storage and configuring cluster quorum.
episodes.title: Failover Clustering Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don completes his explenation of the Failover Cluster feature in Windows Server 2016. He explains the various services that can be clustered for high-availability. He also demonstrates some of the PowerShell commands available for managing a cluster. He completes the show by demonstrating how to test a cluster as well as how to perform routine maintenance tasks to ensure the cluster is running smoothly.
episodes.title: Failover Clustering Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains how Microsoft's Scale-Out File Server role functions in a Windows Server 2016 failover cluster. He explains the use-case scenario for SOFS and then demonstrates how to install and configure SOFS in a cluster using cluster shared volumes.
episodes.title: Scale Out File Server

episodes.description: In this episode, Don introduces the viewers to Storage Spaces Direct (S2D), a new feature in Windows Server 2016. He explains how S2D functions and then demonstrates configuring S2D in a Windows Server 2016 Failover Cluster.
episodes.title: Storage Spaces Direct (S2D)

episodes.description: In this episode, Don icontinues working with Storage Spaces Direct (S2D), a new feature in Windows Server 2016. He begins by demonstrating how to verify S2D is configured correctly. He then moves on to demonstrate how to add virtual disks to a S2D pool and make them available for cluster role storage.
episodes.title: Storage Spaces Direct (S2D) Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains how to deploy Hyper-V virtual machines in a Windows Server 2016 Failover Cluster. He walks through the different storage models available for a Hyper-V cluster and then demonstrates deploying a highly-available VM.
episodes.title: Hyper-V Clusters

episodes.description: In this episode, Don continues working with Hyper-V and Failover Clustering on Windows Server 2016. He demonstrated how to import stand-alone VMs into a Hyper-V cluster. He also demonstrates the three types of migrations available in a Hyper-V cluster: live migration, quick migration, and storage migration.
episodes.title: Hyper-V Clusters Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explore some of the High-Availability Disaster Recovery(HADR) options found in Hyper-V. They begin by implementing Hyper-V Replicas to mitigate server loss down time. Next they start the setup for a live migration, which allows you to move a virtual machine to a new Hyper-V server while the VM is running.
episodes.title: Implement HADR Option in Hyper-V

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike continue their look at High-Availability Disaster Recovery(HADR) options found in Hyper-V. Here they finish their demonstration of the setup and implementation of a live migration.
episodes.title: Implement HADR Option in Hyper-V Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike discuss maintaining Windows Server 2016 through Windows Server Update Services(WSUS). They start by explaining what WSUS is; quickly moving to hardware/software requirements for installation. Then they discuss deployment scenarios and hierarchies.
episodes.title: Maintain Server Installations

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike continue their discussion on maintaining a Windows Server 2016 server, focusing again on Windows Server Update Services. This time They demonstrate and explain the many features in WSUS to familiarize you with this very complex system.
episodes.title: Maintain Server Installations Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explore more ways of maintaining a Windows Server 2016 server using WSUS. Here, they demonstrate the setup and use of WSUS upstream and downstream servers. Next they show you how to setup Automatic Updates. Finally they set client configuration through Group Policy and WSUS groups.
episodes.title: Maintain Server Installations Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike finish their dissertation on maintaining Server installations. Here they will show you how to implement an anti-malware with Windows Defender as well as determining a backup strategy and performing a backup/restore operation using Windows Server Backup.
episodes.title: Maintain Server Installations Part 4

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike introduce you to monitoring Server 2016 installations by employing the Performance Monitor. Here they explore and explain the Performance Monitor's interface and scope of use (collecting data on system functions like CPU, Memory, Disk, and Network).
episodes.title: Monitor Server Installations

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike continue their explanation of the use of the Performance Monitor. They pick back up by looking at Collector Sets; demonstrating how they are used to gather specific data. They also configure alerts and workload monitoring through the Resource Monitor.
episodes.title: Monitor Server Installations Part 2
